message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Proceedings of the 30th International Conference on Intelligent User Interfaces
Paper Abstract: user interfaces mediate between person and machine to increase the ease and effectiveness of user interactions. Research in intelligent user interfaces draws on areas such as artificial and human-computer interaction to study methods for supporting varied users for a wide range of tasks, task environments, platforms, and interaction paradigms. The IUI conference is the annual meeting of the intelligent interfaces community, and serves as the principal international forum for reporting outstanding research and development in intelligent user interfaces. IUI'03, the Seventh IUI, was held at The Palms South Beach hotel in Miami Beach, Florida, USA, from January 12-15, 2003. special theme of the conference was highlighting interfaces whose focus goes beyond rational intelligence to address psychological concerns such as emotion, personality, and motivationIUI'03 solicited submissions in three categories, long papers, describing mature work; short papers, describing work in progress, and brief abstracts of system demonstrations. The conference received 134 submissions, an all-time record, including 80 long papers and 49 short papers. Based on rigorous review by an international program committee, 28 papers were selected for oral presentation, with 45 additional submissions featured as posters and demonstrations. Oral presentations spanned the areas of adaptive and collaborative interfaces, affective interfaces, agent-based interfaces, knowledge acquisition and visualization, model-based interface design, multimodal input, and natural language interfacesThe conference program highlighted three invited talks: Daniel Weld presented What Users Want, Hiroshi Ishii presented Tangible Bits: Designing the Seamless Interface between People, Bits, and Atoms, and Allen Gorin presented Semantic Information Processing of Spoken Language in 'How May I Help You?'  (sm). The panel A Life without Friction: Tales from the InfoLab, chaired by Kristian Hammond and Larry Birnbaum, gave an in-depth view of IUI research at the Information Laboratory of Northwestern University, and the panel XML: The Lingua Franca of IUIs?, chaired by Angel Puerta, examined the role of standardization of interoperation and data interchange in the IUI software industry. The conference opened with two tutorials, Intelligent User Interfaces: An Introduction, by Mark Maybury, and Recommender Systems: Interfaces and Technology, by John Riedl and Joseph Konstan
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed the web search for "Human-Computer Interaction." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".(no content)The term conveys that, unlike other tools with specific and limited uses, computers have many uses which often involve an open-ended dialogue between the user and the computer, with the notion of dialogue likening human–computer interaction to human-to-human interaction.

## Interdisciplinary Nature

Because human–computer interaction studies a human and a machine in communication, it draws from supporting knowledge on both the machine side (computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages) and the human side (communication theory, graphic and industrial design, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, and human factors).

## Key Interaction Areas

HCI encompasses various interaction modalities, including:
- Gesture recognition: identifying and interpreting gestures made by users, often used for direct interaction with computers
- Gaze detection: tracking the movement of a user's eyes to better understand the user's attention, intent, or focus

## Research and Impact

The Human–Computer Interaction Lab (HCIL) at the University of Maryland, College Park is an academic research center specializing in HCI and, founded in 1983 by Ben Shneiderman, it is one of the oldest HCI labs of its kind.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about affective computing:

## Definition and Overview

Affective computing is the study and development of systems and devices that can recognize, interpret, process, and simulate human affects.(no content)It is an interdisciplinary field spanning computer science, psychology, and cognitive science.

## Historical Background

The more modern branch of computer science originated with Rosalind Picard's 1995 paper entitled "Affective Computing" and her 1997 book of the same name published by MIT Press.(no content)One of the motivations for the research is the ability to give machines emotional intelligence, including to simulate empathy.

## Core Goals and Functions

The machine should interpret the emotional state of humans and adapt its behavior to them, giving an appropriate response to those emotions.

## Technologies and Techniques

This is done using machine learning techniques that process different modalities, such as speech recognition, natural language processing, or facial expression detection.(no content)Various changes in the autonomic nervous system can indirectly alter a person's speech, and affective technologies can leverage this information to recognize emotion.

## Applications

Affective computing research has multiple applications, including improved tutoring systems, assistive technology for individuals with autism, and social robotics. Research on affective computing, such as emotional speech recognition and facial expression detection, falls within artificial empathy research.

Web search results for query: "Intelligent agent"

Links: [{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"JACK Intelligent Agents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JACK_Intelligent_Agents"},{"title":"Talk:Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Foundation for Intelligent Physical Agents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundation_for_Intelligent_Physical_Agents"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"Embodied agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embodied_agent"},{"title":"Agentic AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"},{"title":"Virtual assistant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_personal_assistant"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"Intelligence agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Intelligence_agent&redirect=no"}]

Here are the search results for "Intelligent agent":

## Definition

In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

## Key Characteristics

Intelligent agents operate based on an objective function, which encapsulates their goals. They are designed to create and execute plans that maximize the expected value of this function upon completion.(no content)Intelligent agents can range from simple to highly complex. A basic thermostat or control system is considered an intelligent agent, as is a human being, or any other system that meets the same criteria—such as a firm, a state, or a biome.

## Agentic AI (Modern Context)

In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments. Agentic AI tools prioritize decision-making over content creation and do not require human prompts or continuous oversight.

## Examples and Applications

An agent is anything that perceives its environment (using sensors) and acts upon it (using actuators). Examples include a robot with cameras and wheels, or a software program that reads data and makes recommendations.(no content)Related and derived concepts include intelligent agents (in particular exhibiting some aspects of artificial intelligence, such as reasoning), autonomous agents (capable of modifying the methods of achieving their objectives), and multi-agent systems (distributed agents that work together to achieve an objective that could not be accomplished by a single agent acting alone).

In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

## Key Characteristics

Intelligent agents operate based on an objective function, which encapsulates their goals. They are designed to create and execute plans that maximize the expected value of this function upon completion.(no content)Intelligent agents can range from simple to highly complex. A basic thermostat or control system is considered an intelligent agent, as is a human being, or any other system that meets the same criteria—such as a firm, a state, or a biome.

## Agentic AI (Modern Context)

In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments. Agentic AI tools prioritize decision-making over content creation and do not require human prompts or continuous oversight.

## Examples and Applications

An agent is anything that perceives its environment (using sensors) and acts upon it (using actuators). Examples include a robot with cameras and wheels, or a software program that reads data and makes recommendations.(no content)Related and derived concepts include intelligent agents (in particular exhibiting some aspects of artificial intelligence, such as reasoning), autonomous agents (capable of modifying the methods of achieving their objectives), and multi-agent systems (distributed agents that work together to achieve an objective that could not be accomplished by a single agent acting alone).

I've completed the web search for "Artificial Intelligence." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Fundamentals

Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

## History

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Research Goals and Methods

The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.(no content)To reach these goals, AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

## Artificial General Intelligence

Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

## Key Applications

AI has widespread applications across various sectors, including generative artificial intelligence, which is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data. Applications span healthcare, entertainment, military, astronomy, and many other fields.

## Current Challenges

The ethics of artificial intelligence covers a broad range of topics within AI that are considered to have particular ethical stakes, including algorithmic biases, fairness, accountability, transparency, privacy, and regulation, particularly where systems influence or automate human decision-making.

Web search results for query: "Emotion recognition"

Links: [{"title":"Emotion recognition in conversation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion_recognition_in_conversation"},{"title":"Emotion recognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion_recognition"},{"title":"List of facial expression databases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facial_expression_databases"},{"title":"Affective computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_computing"},{"title":"Object recognition (cognitive science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_object_recognition_(animal_test)"},{"title":"OpenSMILE - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenSMILE"},{"title":"Facial expression - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facial_expression"},{"title":"Reverence (emotion) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverence_(emotion)"},{"title":"Face - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_faces"},{"title":"Affectiva - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affectiva"}]

Here's comprehensive information about emotion recognition based on the search results:

## Definition and Overview

Emotion recognition is the process of identifying human emotion.(no content)Use of technology to help people with emotion recognition is a relatively nascent research area, and the technology works best if it uses multiple modalities in context.

## Methods and Modalities

To date, the most work has been conducted on automating the recognition of facial expressions from video, spoken expressions from audio, written expressions from text, and physiology as measured by wearables.(no content)The accuracy of emotion recognition is usually improved when it combines the analysis of human expressions from multimodal forms such as texts, physiology, audio, or video.

## Technical Approaches

Hundreds of different kinds of methods have been proposed and evaluated, leveraging techniques from multiple areas, such as signal processing, machine learning, computer vision, and speech processing.(no content)The existing approaches in emotion recognition can be generally classified into three main categories: knowledge-based techniques, statistical methods, and hybrid approaches.

## Facial Expression Recognition

Facial expression is the motion and positioning of the muscles beneath the skin of the face, and these movements convey the emotional state of an individual to observers and are a form of nonverbal communication.(no content)Most databases are usually based on the basic emotions theory (by Paul Ekman) which assumes the existence of six discrete basic emotions (anger, fear, disgust, surprise, joy, sadness).

## Emotion Recognition in Conversation

Emotion recognition in conversation (ERC) is a sub-field of emotion recognition, that focuses on mining human emotions from conversations or dialogues having two or more interlocutors.

Web search results for query: "Adaptive interface"

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_user_interface"},{"title":"History of adaptive automated instruction in computer applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_automated_adaptive_instruction_in_computer_applications"},{"title":"Talk:Adaptive user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Adaptive_user_interface"},{"title":"Adaptive hypermedia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_hypermedia"},{"title":"Adaptive learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_learning"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Adaptive Internet Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_Internet_Protocol"},{"title":"Attentive user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attentive_user_interface"},{"title":"User interface modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_interface_modeling"},{"title":"Outline of human–computer interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_human-computer_interaction_topics"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about adaptive interfaces:

## Definition

An adaptive user interface (also known as AUI) is a user interface (UI) which adapts, that is changes, its layout and elements to the needs of the user or context and is similarly alterable by each user.

## Key Characteristics

Adaptive UIs allow showing only relevant information based on the current user, which creates less confusion for less experienced users and provides ease of access throughout a system.(no content)A semantic distinction is made between adaptation, referring to system-driven changes for personalization, and adaptability, referring to user-driven changes. Adaptation is automatic, whereas adaptability is not.

## Applications

One common place implementation of an AUI is in the medical industry, where the AUI is used to differentiate and specify which information should be shown to which type of user. Additionally, adaptive hypermedia is used in educational hypermedia, on-line information and help systems, as well as institutional information systems.

## Advantages and Challenges

The advantages of an adaptive user interface are found within its ability to conform to a user's needs, and allow showing only relevant information based on the current user. However, the AUI must be designed with varying levels of implementation in mind and be coupled with a way to measure any particular user's needs, and requires knowing a user's goal in order to most efficiently adapt.

The advantages of an adaptive user interface are found within its ability to conform to a user's needs, and allow showing only relevant information based on the current user. However, the AUI must be designed with varying levels of implementation in mind and be coupled with a way to measure any particular user's needs, and requires knowing a user's goal in order to most efficiently adapt.

Based on the web search results, here's information about adaptive interfaces:

## Definition

An adaptive user interface (also known as AUI) is a user interface (UI) which adapts, that is changes, its layout and elements to the needs of the user or context and is similarly alterable by each user.

## Key Characteristics

Adaptive UIs allow showing only relevant information based on the current user, which creates less confusion for less experienced users and provides ease of access throughout a system.(no content)A semantic distinction is made between adaptation, referring to system-driven changes for personalization, and adaptability, referring to user-driven changes. Adaptation is automatic, whereas adaptability is not.

## Applications

One common place implementation of an AUI is in the medical industry, where the AUI is used to differentiate and specify which information should be shown to which type of user. Additionally, adaptive hypermedia is used in educational hypermedia, on-line information and help systems, as well as institutional information systems.

## Advantages and Challenges

The advantages of an adaptive user interface are found within its ability to conform to a user's needs, and allow showing only relevant information based on the current user. However, the AUI must be designed with varying levels of implementation in mind and be coupled with a way to measure any particular user's needs, and requires knowing a user's goal in order to most efficiently adapt.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Intelligent User Interfaces:

## Definition

An intelligent user interface (intelligent UI, IUI, or sometimes interface agent) is a user interface (UI) that involves some aspect of artificial intelligence (AI or computational intelligence). More specifically, intelligent user interfaces are human–machine interfaces that aim to improve the efficiency, effectiveness, and naturalness of human–machine interaction by representing, reasoning, and acting on models of the user, domain, task, discourse, and media (e.g., graphics, natural language, gesture).

## Historical Evolution

The development of intelligent user interfaces has progressed through several phases. In the early 1980s, as expert systems took hold in the AI community, expert systems were applied to UIs (e.g., the aptly-named "WIZARD" system).(no content)In the 1990s the application of plan inference to interaction formed the basis for research in what then was named natural interfaces.(no content)Later IUIs, such as Clippy, are more statistically-based, using machine learning methods to decide how to tune the interactive experience to the individual user. In the 2000s this strand of research often is labeled personalization, most often employing various recommender system techniques to adapt the behavior of an interface or an entire interactive system to individual user preferences.

## Research and Publication

Research in intelligent user interfaces is published in general Human-Computer Interaction conferences and journals such as CHI or UIST as well as in some artificial intelligence research channels such as those hosted by the AAAI, but most importantly there are the dedicated conference series on Intelligent User Interfaces (since 1988) and Recommender Systems (since 2007), as well as the journal User Modeling and User-Adapted Interaction (since 1990).

Links: [{"title":"Category:Multimodal interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multimodal_interaction"},{"title":"Multimodal interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_interaction"},{"title":"Multimodal Architecture and Interfaces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_Architecture_and_Interfaces"},{"title":"W3C MMI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/W3C_MMI"},{"title":"Cognitive ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_ecology"},{"title":"Sharon Oviatt - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharon_Oviatt"},{"title":"Astatotilapia burtoni - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astatotilapia_burtoni"},{"title":"Multisensory integration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multisensory_integration"},{"title":"Affective computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_computing"}]

## Multimodal Interaction

Based on the search results, here's an overview of multimodal interaction:

### Definition

Multimodal human-computer interaction refers to the "interaction with the virtual and physical environment through natural modes of communication", which enables a more free and natural communication, interfacing users with automated systems in both input and output.

### Key Features

Multimodal systems can offer a flexible, efficient and usable environment allowing users to interact through input modalities, such as speech, handwriting, hand gesture and gaze, and to receive information by the system through output modalities, such as speech synthesis, smart graphics and other modalities, opportunely combined.(no content)The advantage of multiple input modalities is increased usability: the weaknesses of one modality are offset by the strengths of another.

### Processing and Fusion

A multimodal system has to recognize the inputs from the different modalities combining them according to temporal and contextual constraints in order to allow their interpretation. This process is known as multimodal fusion, and it is the object of several research works from the nineties to now.

### Common Examples

The most common such interface combines a visual modality (e.g. a display, keyboard, and mouse) with a voice modality (speech recognition for input, speech synthesis and recorded audio for output).

### Research and Standards

The Multimodal Interaction Activity is an initiative from W3C aiming to provide means (mostly XML) to support Multimodal interaction scenarios on the Web. This activity was launched in 2002.

Based on the web search results, here's information about collaborative interfaces:

## Overview

A collaborative interface is a key component of computer-based systems that support groups of people engaged in a common task (or goal) and that provide an interface to a shared environment. These interfaces are part of the broader field of computer-supported cooperative work (CSCW), which is the study of how people utilize technology collaboratively, often towards a shared goal.

## Key Functions

Collaborative interfaces serve multiple purposes in enabling teamwork:

- A collaboration tool helps people to collaborate, with the purpose of supporting a group of two or more individuals to accomplish a common goal or objective
- CSCW addresses how computer systems can support collaborative activity and coordination

## Types of Collaborative Interfaces

Collaborative interfaces vary based on their functionality:

- Real-time collaborative editing platforms allow multiple users to engage in live, simultaneous, and reversible editing of a single file (usually a document)
- A collaborative real-time editor enables real-time collaborative editing, simultaneous editing, or live editing of the same digital document by different users on different computers or mobile devices, with automatic and nearly instantaneous merging of their edits

These interfaces have become essential in modern work environments, enabling teams to coordinate efforts and share information effectively across distances and time zones.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about natural language interfaces:

## Definition

A natural-language user interface (LUI or NLUI) is a type of computer human interface where linguistic phenomena such as verbs, phrases and clauses act as UI controls for creating, selecting and modifying data in software applications.

## How It Works

Natural-language search attempts to use natural-language processing to understand the nature of the question and then to search and return a subset of the web that contains the answer to the question. For example, a natural-language search engine would in theory find targeted answers to user questions (as opposed to keyword search).

## Applications

Examples include voice assistants, such as Alexa and Siri, touch and multitouch interactions on today's mobile phones and tablets, but also touch interfaces invisibly integrated into the textiles of furniture.

## Related Technologies

Natural language interfaces are often distinguished from related concepts. A conversational user interface (CUI) is a user interface for computers that emulates a conversation with a human.(no content)CUIs provide opportunity for the user to communicate with the computer in their natural language rather than in syntax specific commands, and conversational interfaces use natural language processing (NLP) to allow computers to understand, analyze, and create meaning from human language.

## Challenges

One key challenge is that natural-language interfaces have in the past led users to anthropomorphize the computer, or at least to attribute more intelligence to machines than is warranted, leading to unrealistic expectations of the capabilities of the system and ultimately disappointment when the system fails to perform as expected.

Web search results for query: "Motivation psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Motivation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motivation"},{"title":"Motivation crowding theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motivation_crowding_theory"},{"title":"Industrial and organizational psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_and_organizational_psychology"},{"title":"Work motivation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Work_motivation"},{"title":"Self-determination theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-determination_theory"},{"title":"Psychology of learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology_of_learning"},{"title":"Sport psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_psychology"},{"title":"Dalbir Bindra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dalbir_Bindra"},{"title":"Magdalen Dorothea Vernon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magdalen_Dorothea_Vernon"},{"title":"Drive theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drive_theory"}]

Here are the search results for "Motivation psychology":

## Definition and Overview

Motivation is an internal state that propels individuals to engage in goal-directed behavior.(no content)It is often understood as a force that explains why people or other animals initiate, continue, or terminate a certain behavior at a particular time.

## Key Components

Motivation involves three psychological processes: arousal, direction, and intensity. More specifically:
- Arousal is what initiates action and is often fueled by a person's need or desire for something that is missing from their life.
- Direction refers to the path employees take in accomplishing the goals they set for themselves.
- Intensity is the amount of energy employees put into goal-directed work performance, with the level of intensity often reflecting the importance and difficulty of the goal.

## Major Theories

**Intrinsic vs. Extrinsic Motivation:** Intrinsic motivation refers to initiating an activity because it is interesting and satisfying to do so, as opposed to doing an activity to obtain an external goal (i.e., from extrinsic motivation).

**Drive Theory:** Drive theory is based on the principle that organisms are born with certain psychological needs and that a negative state of tension is created when these needs are not satisfied. When a need is satisfied, drive is reduced and the organism returns to a state of homeostasis and relaxation.

**Self-Determination Theory:** Self-determination theory is rooted in the psychology of intrinsic motivation, drawing upon the complexities of human motivation and the factors that foster or hinder autonomous engagement in activities.

Web search results for query: "Personality psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Personality psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_psychology"},{"title":"Journal of Personality and Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Personality_and_Social_Psychology"},{"title":"Society for Personality and Social Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_Personality_and_Social_Psychology"},{"title":"Personality and Social Psychology Review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_and_Social_Psychology_Review"},{"title":"Personality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality"},{"title":"Personality test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_test"},{"title":"Personality type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_type"},{"title":"Individual psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Individual_psychology"},{"title":"Personality development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_development"},{"title":"Analytical psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analytical_psychology"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about personality psychology:

## Definition and Scope

Personality psychology is a branch of psychology that examines personality and its variation among individuals, aiming to show how people are individually different due to psychological forces.(no content)Personality is defined as a dynamic and organized set of characteristics possessed by an individual that uniquely influences their environment, cognition, emotions, motivations, and behaviors in various situations.

## Focus Areas

Research in personality psychology generally attempts to explain the characteristics of a person that underlie differences in behavior, and personality characteristics are related to many life outcomes, such as work and relationship success, to mental health, well-being and longevity.

## Major Theoretical Approaches

The major theories include dispositional (trait) perspective, psychodynamic, humanistic, biological, behaviorist, evolutionary, and social learning perspective.(no content)The first theorists in the field include Sigmund Freud, Alfred Adler, Gordon Allport, Hans Eysenck, Abraham Maslow, and Carl Rogers.

## Types vs. Traits

Personality type refers to the psychological classification of people into different classes, and personality types are distinguished from personality traits, which come in different degrees.(no content)Personality type theories have fallen out of favor in psychology, and most researchers now believe that it is impossible to explain the diversity of human personality with a small number of discrete types, recommending trait models instead, such as the five-factor model.

## The Big Five Model

The most widely accepted empirical model of durable, universal personality descriptors is the system of Big Five personality traits: conscientiousness, agreeableness, neuroticism, openness to experience, and extraversion-introversion.

Personality psychology is a branch of psychology that examines personality and its variation among individuals, aiming to show how people are individually different due to psychological forces.(no content)Personality is defined as a dynamic and organized set of characteristics possessed by an individual that uniquely influences their environment, cognition, emotions, motivations, and behaviors in various situations.

## Focus Areas

Research in personality psychology generally attempts to explain the characteristics of a person that underlie differences in behavior, and personality characteristics are related to many life outcomes, such as work and relationship success, to mental health, well-being and longevity.

## Major Theoretical Approaches

The major theories include dispositional (trait) perspective, psychodynamic, humanistic, biological, behaviorist, evolutionary, and social learning perspective.(no content)The first theorists in the field include Sigmund Freud, Alfred Adler, Gordon Allport, Hans Eysenck, Abraham Maslow, and Carl Rogers.

## Types vs. Traits

Personality type refers to the psychological classification of people into different classes, and personality types are distinguished from personality traits, which come in different degrees.(no content)Personality type theories have fallen out of favor in psychology, and most researchers now believe that it is impossible to explain the diversity of human personality with a small number of discrete types, recommending trait models instead, such as the five-factor model.

## The Big Five Model

The most widely accepted empirical model of durable, universal personality descriptors is the system of Big Five personality traits: conscientiousness, agreeableness, neuroticism, openness to experience, and extraversion-introversion.

Based on the Wikipedia search results, here's what I found about Human-Computer Interaction:

## Definition

Human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems.(no content)Research in HCI covers the design and the use of computer technology, which focuses on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

## Scope and Disciplines

The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".(no content)HCI studies a human and a machine in communication and draws from supporting knowledge on both sides—on the machine side, techniques in computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages, and development environments are relevant, while on the human side, communication theory, graphic and industrial design disciplines, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, social psychology, and human factors are relevant.

## Alternative Terms

HCI is also sometimes termed human–machine interaction (HMI), man-machine interaction (MMI) or computer-human interaction (CHI).

## Key Aspects

A key aspect of HCI is user satisfaction, also referred to as End-User Computing Satisfaction.

The search results show that HCI is a comprehensive field that bridges computer science and behavioral sciences, with a focus on creating effective and user-friendly interactions between people and computers.

Based on the search results from Wikipedia, here's an overview of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI):

## Definition

The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them". More simply, human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems, and research in HCI covers the design and the use of computer technology, which focuses on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

## Scope and Multidisciplinary Nature

As a field of research, human–computer interaction is situated at the intersection of computer science, behavioral sciences, design, media studies, and several other fields.(no content)HCI researchers observe how people interact with computers and design technologies that allow humans to interact with computers in new ways.

## Types of Interaction

These include visual, auditory, and tactile (haptic) feedback systems, which serve as channels for interaction in both traditional interfaces and mobile computing contexts.(no content)Desktop applications, web browsers, handheld computers, and computer kiosks make use of the prevalent graphical user interfaces (GUIs) of today, while voice user interfaces (VUIs) are used for speech recognition and synthesizing systems.

## Alternative Terms

HCI is also sometimes termed human–machine interaction (HMI), man-machine interaction (MMI) or computer-human interaction (CHI).
